documents.document: 770: In the West Byzantium still ruled Sardinia; Sicily: governor at Syracuse; just the foot and heel of Italy; Venice; ports in Dalmatia.
770s: Byzantine Sicily produced several iconodule martyrs. The emperor had Methodius of Syracuse scourged +confined underground for 7 years.
C8th: The Roman (Byzantine) Empire minted coins at Syracuse, Ravenna, Rome. Gold coins continued after 751 when Ravenna fell 2 the Lombards.
740: Large campaign by Muslims of Ifriqiya [Tunisia] ag. Byzantine Syracuse. Countryside ravaged; but called back bc of a revolt at home.
726-727: Willibald, an Anglo-Saxon pilgrim, sailed home via to Syracuse: on a ship carrying envoys of the Pope w letters from the Emperor.
c.723: Willibald, an Anglo-Saxon pilgrim to Constantinople & t East, stopped at Byzantine Syracuse. Not the most direct route. Trading ship?
Sicily 718: The Byzantine governor rebels & declares a counter-emperor in Syracuse. T revolt is put down by a flotilla from Constantinople.
704: Muslim flotilla from "Ifriqiya" [Tunisia] raids the Empire’s outer islands: Balearics, Sicily, Sardinia. Syracuse sacked? (unclear).
Late C7th: Civilian sea trade moribund. Coins struck in Byzantine Carthage, Rome & Syracuse found in the Danube delta wd be due to the navy.
Arabic sources point to a date of AD 668-69, but the contemporary Liber Pontificalis says in the time of pope Adeodatus, acc. 672.
SE Sicily 669: Arab sea-raiders from Egypt led by ‘Abd’Allah b.Qays briefly take & devastate Byzantine Syracuse. (Tunisia still Byzantine.)
668: Did the teenage Constantine IV, son & heir to t assassinated Constans II, gather a fleet and personally proceed to Syracuse? Disputed.
668: The army of Byzantine Italy ("exercitus Italiae") seized Syracuse & killed the usurper Mezezius. His head was taken 2 Constantinople.
Syracuse 668: Roman (Byzantine) emperor assassinated. His military commander, Mizizios, perhaps unwillingly or reluctantly, is proclaimed.
Byzantium 668: emperor Constans II was assassinated at Syracuse. His son brought the seat of government back to New Rome (Constantinople).
660s: Neither Greek, nor Syriac, nor Arabic writers speak abt the Emperor's sojourn in Syracuse. Information only from the West (Latin).
AD 663: Emperor Constans temporarily transfers his HQ to Syracuse, presumably 2 shore up the crumbling structure of imperial rule in t West.
The 'End of Antiquity': After AD 600 only one city in Western Europe shows evidence of an abundant copper coinage, namely Byzantine Rome.

Akakia: a cylinder w jewelled ends containing dust, held by Byzantine emperors at ceremonies. Symbolising mortality, hence his own humility.
949: N Italian king's ambassador 2 Constantinople records jewelled organs; a mechanical throne; and a tree of gold w singing metal birds...
AD 917 Byzantine embassy 2 the East. The Arabs laid out massive amounts of precious objects, jewels, “22,000” carpets, “38,000” tapestries.
C9th: The Kievan Rus' sold slaves & furs above all; also amber, honey, wax; 2 buy Byzantine silk, jewellery, brocades, fruits, wine, spices.
Byzantine imperial triumph 831: a white charger w jewelled harness; his cuirass under a gold tunic embroidered w a design of roses & grapes.
John VIII, 1430s: In t jewel-studded bulbous-domed crown & pendilia (side pearls) of Late Byzantium. Or large high-crowned mitre-like hat.
1376: Byzantium sold the island of Tenedos 2 the Venetians for 30,000 ducats plus return of the Byzantine crown jewels. Not carried thru.
@MoiraR Roman (Byzantine) emperor Herakleios was failing militarily. The Shah taunted him that soon Constantinople wd fall. Chosroes fell.
1346-47: Rich Serbia, shabby Byzantium: Dushan crowned in bejewelled gold. Kantakouzenos wore one of coloured glass set in gilded leather.
1343: Byzantine crown jewels pawned to Venice, never to return. They may have been melted down when Napoleon conquered Venice in 1797.
Constantinople 1331: Byzantine wife of Kipchak khan arrives. Her brother under a jewelled parasol; his men in jewelled helmets. Ibn Battuta.

c.623: "Chosroes [of Persia] 2 Heraclius his vile and insensate slave: ...Have I not destroyed u Romans ...you trust in God; why then(etc)".
780: Byzantine emp. Leo IV dies, aged only 31. Illness supposedly contracted from his wearing the jewelled church crown from Hagia Sophia.
Constantinople 17.vii.1203: Franco-Venetian assault on 2 sides. Alexios III flees to Thrace taking the state treasury & crown jewels w him.
Byzantine emp. Manuel 1159: jewelled purple robe over golden [gilded] mail armour, & a jewelled diadem “dripping w pearls [i.e. pendilia]”.
